awd_titl_txt: EAGER Collaborative: >100 GHz Optical Clocking using Self-Modulation of Co-Tunneling Light Emitters
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to explore a new class of ultra-fast optical emitters. Those optical emitters will provide (i) for the significant advancement of direct modulation optical emitters, and (ii) creation of a wholly new optical emission pathway which is expected to exceed previous designs, while mitigating efficiency losses. Applications of such devices include fast clocks, and systems such as optical communication and LIDAR.
Through a collaboration between the Ohio State University and the Wright State University, a significant exposure to research, particularly under-represented groups, will help to advance the field of RTD-based emitters while providing for a haven of educational nurturing. The team will also focus appropriate results of this the research output towards strategic commercialization.
The collaborative team will explore this new class of resonant-tunneling-diode (RTD)-based emitters as a source of ultra-fast direct modulation emitters. It is believed that, since the slow holes are generated without highly resistive p-type doping and are created by Zener tunneling exactly at the point of carrier recombination and optical emission, these optical emitters will bypass many of the slow mechanisms that have prohibited fast direct optical emitters in the past. A key focus of this project is working on cavity design, balancing of hole and electron currents using the PIs own hybrid combined analytical-numerical physics models, design and modeling of thermal management and heat extraction, fabrication and testing of ultra-fast direct modulation light emitters. The aim is to achieve the first demonstration of ultra-fast direct modulation using quantum co-tunneling. The expected impact of the research includes: 1) Low-cost, ultra-fast optical sources, and (2) self-clocking optical emitters for compact clock signal generation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project established a bi-university collaborative project (Ohio State and Wright State) in new RTD-based optical sources, discovered by this team, that advanced the field of quantum tunneling based optical generation and modulation. Through a discovery never observed before for unipolar-doped InGaAs based RTDs, infrared light emission was observed from bipolar cross bandgap InGaAs recombination. This followed the team’s accidental discovery of RTD visible light emission from nascent GaN/AlN RTDs that were first published in a peer-reviewed venue by this team. Thus, the universality of this bipolar emission from unipolar-doped RTDs seems possible. No p-type doping is required and a very short path length for slow holes is contained. Thus, this could allow for higher power light emission and faster light modulation.

 

Broader Impacts: Through collaborations between OSU and WSU, and significant exposure to undergraduate research, this project helped to advance the field of RTD-based emitters while providing for a haven of educational nurturing. The team also focused appropriate results of this the research output towards strategic commercialization.

 

Project Outcomes: Light emission was observed from InGaAs RTDs using injected holes and cross-gap recombination with resonant tunneling electrons, as shown in the Primary Image.

Theoretical modeling advanced a more complete picture of the internal physics, showing a competition between impact ionization and Zener tunneling to produce holes near the active recombination zone. Impact ionization is present at lower biases, and when the internal field rises, Zener tunneling exponentially rises and takes over as the dominant hole generation mechanism. Covid-19 shutdowns and high personnel turnover thwarted progress with experimental progress, where high-speed operation was found to require a Fabry-Perot etalon to enhance stimulated emission over the slower spontaneous light emission. Nevertheless, significant workforce training took place. Ohio State’s Co-PI is a USA veteran, who initiated the initial discoveries and moved to the Naval Research Lab, first as a prestigious NRC Fellowship, followed by member-of-technical staff. Six undergraduate researchers followed thereafter, three of whom stayed on at Ohio State for advanced graduate degrees (PhD completed, Masters completed and Masters-track) and two more of the six continued towards graduate degrees (both Masters) elsewhere. Further, the completed Masters degree student continued on for a PhD with another advisor, leading to at minimum a 3-2-1 (PhD, Masters, BSE) NSF REU impact.

Modified by: Paul R Berger
